questions.question: Which division of the nervous system is based on physical structures and location?
questions.feedback: The anatomical division classifies the nervous system by physical structures and location.

questions.question: Which term refers to a direction toward the front of the body?
questions.feedback: Rostral (or anterior) means toward the front of the body.

questions.question: Which anatomical plane divides the body into left and right halves?
questions.feedback: The sagittal plane divides the body into left and right halves.

questions.question: Which structure is part of the central nervous system?
questions.feedback: The central nervous system includes the brain and spinal cord.

questions.question: Which component belongs to the peripheral nervous system?
questions.feedback: Cranial nerves are part of the peripheral nervous system.

questions.question: Afferent signals carry information:
questions.feedback: Afferent pathways carry sensory information from the body to the CNS.

questions.question: Efferent signals are mainly responsible for:
questions.feedback: Efferent pathways carry motor commands from the CNS to the body.

questions.question: Which system controls voluntary skeletal muscle movement?
questions.feedback: The somatic nervous system controls voluntary skeletal muscle activity.

questions.question: Most autonomic nervous system activity occurs:
questions.feedback: Autonomic regulation usually occurs without conscious awareness.

questions.question: Which branch of the autonomic nervous system supports fight-or-flight responses?
questions.feedback: The sympathetic nervous system prepares the body for action.

questions.question: Which effect is typical of sympathetic activation?
questions.feedback: Sympathetic activation increases heart rate and causes bronchodilation.

questions.question: Which branch of the autonomic nervous system promotes rest and digestion?
questions.feedback: The parasympathetic nervous system supports recovery and homeostasis.

questions.question: Which brain division includes the cerebrum?
questions.feedback: The cerebrum is part of the forebrain.

questions.question: The two cerebral hemispheres are connected by:
questions.feedback: The corpus callosum connects the left and right hemispheres.

questions.question: Gyri are best described as:
questions.feedback: Gyri are the raised ridges of the cerebral cortex.

questions.question: Which lobe is primarily involved in voluntary movement and executive control?
questions.feedback: The frontal lobe is involved in motor control and executive functions.

questions.question: Damage to the parietal lobe may result in:
questions.feedback: Parietal lobe damage can cause spatial neglect, especially after right hemisphere lesions.

questions.question: Which lobe is primarily dedicated to visual processing?
questions.feedback: The occipital lobe is dedicated to visual processing.

questions.question: Which subcortical structure is essential for forming new long-term memories?
questions.feedback: The hippocampus is critical for forming new long-term memories.

questions.question: Which structure assigns emotional value to stimuli?
questions.feedback: The amygdala plays a key role in emotional processing and threat detection.

questions.question: Damage to the basal nuclei primarily disrupts:
questions.feedback: Basal nuclei damage disrupts movement regulation without causing paralysis.

questions.question: Which diencephalic structure relays sensory information to cortex?
questions.feedback: The thalamus relays and modulates sensory information to cortex.

questions.question: Which structure links the nervous and endocrine systems?
questions.feedback: The hypothalamus connects neural activity to hormonal regulation.

questions.question: Which structure is essential for breathing and heart rate control?
questions.feedback: The brainstem controls vital functions such as breathing and heart rate.

questions.question: Which are the three subdivisions of the brainstem?
questions.feedback: The brainstem consists of the midbrain, pons, and medulla.

questions.question: Damage to the cerebellum primarily affects:
questions.feedback: Cerebellar damage causes inaccurate and uncoordinated movements.

questions.question: Cranial nerves are part of the:
questions.feedback: Cranial nerves belong to the peripheral nervous system.

questions.question: How many pairs of cranial nerves are there?
questions.feedback: There are 12 pairs of cranial nerves, numbered I to XII.

questions.question: Which cranial nerve provides extensive parasympathetic innervation?
questions.feedback: The vagus nerve provides major parasympathetic innervation to thoracic and abdominal organs.

questions.question: Which spinal root carries sensory information into the spinal cord?
questions.feedback: The dorsal root carries sensory information into the spinal cord.
